statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

article.description: Jayson Tatum took over in the final two minutes, making key plays on both ends of the floor, and No. 14 Duke became the first team to win the ACC with four wins in four days.

video.headline: Coach K talks grueling ACC tournament schedule
video.caption: Mike Krzyzewski talks about playing four games in four days en route to winning the finals over Notre Dame.
video.description: Mike Krzyzewski talks about playing four games in four days en route to winning the finals over Notre Dame.
video.title: Coach K talks grueling ACC tournament schedule

article.headline: Duke downs Notre Dame to become first 4-in-4 ACC champion

images.name: Coach K talks grueling ACC tournament schedule
images.caption: Mike Krzyzewski talks about playing four games in four days en route to winning the finals over Notre Dame.

article.linkText: Duke wins 4 games in 4 days to claim ACC title
article.story:
NEW YORK -- In a season that has been anything but routine for Duke, the Blue Devils won the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament as it had never been done before.

Jayson Tatum took over in the final three minutes, making key plays all over the floor, and No. 14 Duke became the first team to win the event with four victories in four days by rallying past No. 22 Notre Dame 75-69 on Saturday night.

The freshman forward finished a spectacular week in Brooklyn with 19 points and eight rebounds for the fifth-seeded Blue Devils (27-8). Duke won its first ACC tournament championship since 2011 and its 20th overall, most in league history, and the 14th under coach Mike Krzyzewski.

"I've been on a lot of good journeys, but this was such a good one," the 70-year-old Krzyzewski said.

Bonzie Colson was a beast for third-seeded Notre Dame (25-9), with 29 points and nine rebounds.

"It's one of the great performances in championship game history," said Notre Dame coach Mike Brey, the former Krzyzewski assistant who is now 5-4 against Duke with the Irish.

The Blue Devils came from double digits down in the second half to beat both No. 10 Louisville and No. 6 North Carolina to get to the finals at Barclays Center and then came from eight back with 11:35 left to defeat the Irish.

"Four games in four days is not an easy task," Duke guard Grayson Allen said. "At the end of the day it was all emotion and heart getting us through those games."

And a lot of Tatum on Saturday night.

He made a running hook to give Duke a 65-62 lead, but Colson's 3-pointer with 2:25 left tied it.

Tatum hit one of two free throws to put Duke back in front, and then came through with the play of the night. Or make that, the plays of the night.

He blocked Steve Vasturia's drive to the hoop and then went coast to coast for a layup to make it 68-65 with 1:33 left.

"I thought, 'What are you doing?'" Krzyzewski said about Tatum taking off with the ball. "'Yes! You did it. How the hell did you do that?' I thought it gave everyone energy."

Matt Farrell pulled Notre Dame within two with a couple of free throws before Tatum showed off another skill, driving and dishing to Matt Jones for a 3 to make it 71-67 with 50 seconds remaining. It was Jones' only basket of the game.

"It was the shot of the game," Krzyzewski said.

Tatum then all but sealed it, getting behind the defense on an inbounds pass from Jones for a slam while being fouled. Tatum completed the three-point play for a 74-69 advantage with 25 seconds left.

Luke Kennard had 16 points for Duke and was selected tournament MVP, but it was really Tatum's time to shine. He averaged 22 points and 7.5 rebounds in four games.

BIG PICTURE

Duke: The Blue Devils started the season No. 1 in the country for the eighth time, but the road to this championship has been uneven.

"They've been through so much, so they're close," Krzyzewski said. "That closeness is what got them through tonight."

There was Allen's suspension for tripping an opponent. Krzyzewski missed seven games early in the conference season to have back surgery. Soon after he left, the Blue Devils lost three of four to start 3-4 in ACC play. The nadir was the program's first loss to NC State at Cameron Indoor Stadium since 1995.

After that game there was a report by ESPN that Coach K, still recovering, held a meeting at his home with players, and forbade them to use their locker room or wear Duke gear.

Allen hurt his ankle and the Blue Devils finished the regular season losing three of four. They came to Brooklyn looking like a flawed team.

Now it all seems to be coming together.

"We're a group of fighters and I think it shows. A big part of that is (Krzyzewski) and his leadership," Allen said.

Notre Dame: The Irish can look no further than their 6-for-25 performance from 3-point range to explain why they came up short. V.J. Beachem and Farrell each went 1 for 6. That's a tough way for a team that usually shoots 39 percent from 3 to win.

UP NEXT

Duke: How far will the Blue Devils' late surge push them up the NCAA seed chart? A No. 1 seed has never had as many as eight losses.

Notre Dame: Another NCAA tournament awaits the Irish. They have reached the round of eight the last two years.

"We learn from here. We grow," Colson said. "Just a tough one. But we have a whole new season to go and we still have an opportunity to cut down some nets."

videos.headline: Jackson drives to make the contested layup
videos.description: Duke's Frank Jackson drives to the basket to put in the layup for the Blue Devils.

videos.headline: Kennard with the four-point play
videos.description: Duke's Grayson Allen finds Luke Kennard in the corner for the 3-pointer and Kennard draws the foul.

videos.headline: Giles throws down alley-oop
videos.description: Duke's Grayson Allen finds Harry Giles for a first-half dunk against Notre Dame.

videos.headline: Tatum with the vicious putback
videos.description: Duke's Luke Kennard misses the 3-pointer and Jayson Tatum is there for the strong putback dunk.

videos.headline: Allen makes a move for the and-1
videos.description: Duke's Grayson Allen drives to the basket, makes a move in the air and finishes with the and-1.

videos.headline: Colson with the hoop and harm
videos.description: Notre Dame's Bonzi Colson makes the layup and draws the foul with under ten seconds in the first half.

videos.headline: Allen lays it in at the first-half buzzer
videos.description: Duke's Grayson Allen gets the lay-in right as the buzzer sounds in the first half over Notre Dame.

videos.headline: Farrell drives and draws the foul
videos.description: Notre Dame's Matt Farrell drives to the basket and somehow gets the ball to fall while drawing a foul.

videos.headline: Colson gets a pair of baskets to help the Fighting Irish
videos.description: Notre Dame's Bonzi Colson hits a long jumper and makes a contested layup to help the Fighting Irish stay competitive against Duke.

videos.headline: Notre Dame's steal and dunk
videos.description: Notre Dame's Bonzie Colson gets the steal from Duke's Grayson Allen and the Fighting Irish's V.J. Beachem hammers down the dunk off the Colson missed layup.

videos.headline: Duke's turnovers get costly
videos.description: Duke's Grayson Allen turns over the ball again and Notre Dame's V.J. Beachem dunks it after a Bonzi Colson steal.

videos.headline: Colson goes down with apparent ankle injury
videos.description: Notre Dame's Bonzi Colson heads to the locker room with an apparent ankle injury in the second half against Duke, but would return to the game.

videos.headline: Colson loses contact lens
videos.description: Notre Dame's Bonzi Colson loses his contact lens and has to go to the bench to put in a new one.

videos.headline: Tatum turns defense into offense
videos.description: Duke's Jayson Tatum gets a block and goes coast-to-coast for the layup late in the second half against Notre Dame.

videos.headline: Tatum slams down the dagger for Duke
videos.description: Duke's Jayson Tatum dunks off the inbounds pass and draws the foul to help seal the victory for the Blue Devils.

videos.headline: Duke celebrates ACC tournament win
videos.description: The Blue Devils celebrate their 75-69 win over Notre Dame in the ACC tournament final.

videos.headline: Tatum talks emotion in winning ACC tournament
videos.description: Duke's Jayson Tatum talks about what it feels like to come out on top against Notre Dame to win the ACC tournament 75-69.

videos.headline: Coach K lifts ACC tournament trophy for 14th time
videos.description: Duke head coach Mike Krzyzewski jokes with ESPN analyst and former Blue Devil Jay Bilas about the talent level of first ACC tournament champions and the 2017 ACC tournament champions.
